arm_group.description: Web based self-monitoring of problematic alcohol and drug use.
No intervention except for assessment of alcohol and drug use.

brief_summary.textblock:
Objectives: This study evaluates the efficacy of eScreen for internet psychiatry patients
      treated for major depressive disorder, panic anxiety and social phobia. The eScreen brief
      Internet intervention for problematic alcohol and drug use offers self-screening, in-depth
      self-reporting, personalized feedback and treatment recommendations as well as an electronic
      diary. Progress over time is shown in diagrams detailing consumption levels.

      Method: This is a two-armed randomized controlled design, measuring outcomes in terms of
      changes in problematic alcohol use up to one year after study recruitment. Participants with
      problematic alcohol use (AUDIT >7 for men and >5 for women) and/or problematic drug use
      (DUDIT > 1 for both men and women) are randomized into one of two groups: T1, eScreen
      referral or Control group. Outcomes on alcohol and drug use as well as health-related
      symptoms are assessed after 3, 6 and 12 months.

      The hypothesis is that the group receiving the eScreen intervention will reduce their
      alcohol/drug use to a larger extent than the control group at follow-up compared to the
      baseline level.

clinical_study.brief_title: Substance-use Focused Screening and Brief Intervention as a Complement to Internet-based Psychiatric Treatment for Depression, Panic Disorder or Social Phobia: A Randomized Controlled Trial

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

        AUDIT >7 for men and AUDIT >5 for women, and/or DUDIT >0

        Exclusion Criteria:

        DUDIT = 0 and AUDIT <8 (men) or <6 (women)

intervention.intervention_name: Assessment only of alcohol and drug use.

facility.name: Karolinska institutet, Department of Clinical Neuroscience, Center for Psychiatric Research

other_outcome.description: Health-related questions on wellbeing, sleep, concentration, energy, social life, sadness and current life meaning, etc.
other_outcome.measure: Changes in health parameters over time

primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome measure for this trial is the change in the total AUDIT score for the first three AUDIT questions, as a measure of alcohol consumption only, referred to as the AUDIT-C.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in the total AUDIT-C score

reference.citation: Sinadinovic K, Berman AH, Hasson D, Wennberg P. Internet-based assessment and self-monitoring of problematic alcohol and drug use. Addict Behav. 2010 May;35(5):464-70. doi: 10.1016/j.addbeh.2009.12.021. Epub 2010 Jan 4. Erratum in: Addict Behav. 2010 Sep;35(9):853.

Sinadinovic K, Wennberg P, Berman AH. Targeting problematic users of illicit drugs with Internet-based screening and brief intervention: a randomized controlled trial. Drug Alcohol Depend. 2012 Nov 1;126(1-2):42-50. doi: 10.1016/j.drugalcdep.2012.04.016. Epub 2012 May 20.

Sinadinovic, K., Wennberg, P., & Berman, A. H. (2013). Internet-based Screening and Brief Intervention for Illicit Drug Users: A Randomized Controlled Trial with 12-month Follow-Up. Journal of Studies on Alcohol and Drugs, In press.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Change in total AUDIT score, as a summarized measure of alcohol use (including alcohol consumption and alcohol-related problems).

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator), Primary Purpose: Treatment
